I mean, you can easily settle this debate by the products they use.

Cereal is not a soup, it is not processed, prepared, or cooked. By those requirements it is not a soup, what dishes brought up are indeed soups, cereal itself which is just grain and milk do not fit those requirements just because it's a liquid in a container. By that logic then a glass of milk can be classified as soup or cereal dish.

More defining evidence is the liquids they contain:
broth is its own substance, milk is already a liquid product on its own so it cannot enter itself as a broth as broth is a liquid which is a product created by cooking itself, so no broth no soup. Milk is natural broth is not, cereal cannot be defined as a soup dish by that definition.

Pours the milk: WHAT THE HECK IS THIS?

salad is made of veggies that are made of 95% or so water, so salad is only 5% away from being soup

but is cereal 100% soup or 95%?

the answer is actually 96.75%

you see, the liquid part of soup is water, in a soup soup, the solids are meat or pasta or other veggies

in a 95% soup aka salad, the water is in the lettuce, and the solids are variable, bread, other veggies, potato, nuts, etc.

what about cereal? well the dry stuff doesn't have much water in it, it is the solid stuff like the meat or potatoes or bread or nuts in the other examples. As for the water portion, milk is actually 3.25% fat (varies depending on the type of milk) so because the liquid part of cereal is 3.25% fat, the water portion is 96.75%

In conclusion, soup soup is 100% soup, salad soup is 95% soup, and cereal is 96.75% soup. According to these numbers, linearly cereal is closer to being salad than soup but not because of the milk being dressing, it's because the liquid portion of each are 95% and 96.75% water and soup soup is 100%.

I remember a few years ago I overheard some classmates debating this topic and decided to research whether or not cereal was a soup for my homework, as a joke. And I debated that for anyone who says soup is a dinner food and cereal is a breakfast one. That in Sweden they have a blueberry soup that they typically eat for breakfast. It's called Blabarssoppa. Essentially it is boiled blueberries with cornstarch and sweeteners. So, if that is considered soup then cereal is soup. And that goes along with other things like cream of wheat, oatmeal, ect. Following along with Micheal's,  "Is milk the icing to the cereal?" question; I stated that milk is to cereal as chicken broth is to vegetables. ((Keep in mind I defined soup as a thick or thin liquid with added chunks for texture or flavour. Which both the blueberry soup and cereal fall into that criteria.))

Cereal isn't soup because when you ask for it you don't have to specify "Can I have a bowl of Cereal Soup", like you have to do when you say "Can I have a bowl of Chicken Soup ". With Chicken, if you didn't specify that you wanted Chicken Soup, you would get a bowl of Chicken. The same goes for Tomatoes or Vegetarian or any other kind of soup. That never happens with Cereal and if you ask any regular person who knows anything about Cereal  to bring you a bowl of Cereal, they would always bring you Cereal with milk added. Even if you were lactose intolerant, you would be given a bowl of Cereal with a Milk substitute like Soy or Almond Milk. In fact, I will emphatically state that when asked for Cereal, no one ever gives another person a bowl of Milk-less cereal unless A) they are out of Milk and in that case they would most likely apologize for being out of Milk or B) they are some kind of douchebag prick that likes busting balls or C) if they were not of this planet and were some kind of alien species from outer space, most likely planning on colonizing the planet and trying to fit in until they can take over the planet, but in the mean time constantly exposing themselves as aliens and generally fucking it up royally!

Is Pizza a sandwich?

You add milk to cereal, an already edible artificial food, to make a combo to get a very good taste.

You can eat cereal cold and hot, both offer different taste and pleasure. You know what isn't supposed to be eaten cold? A soup.

Milk comes from animals, and soup always has natural plants and meat occasionally in the recipe. So that means cereal doesn't have plants nor meat which both are the stereotypes of a soup.

So that is it, cereal can be eaten hot and cold (without feeling like you're wasting your life eating a crappy food), it doesn't have ingredients found 100% in nature nor does it use plants or meat for it's making.

(You can also eat cereal dry, but it depends on the brand and how dependent on the milk and cereal combo.)

Edit: Cereal can also have chocolate in them, even if the argument that few brands put chocolate in it doesn't really prove that you can add chocolate to soup and still be moral.

short answer: no


long answer: Of course cereal isn’t a soup, you reassure yourself, cereal isn’t hot. And indeed, you may have a point there. No less of an authority than Dictionary.com defines soup as “a liquid food made by boiling or simmering meat, fish, or vegetables with various added ingredients.”


But aren’t cold, liquid-base dishes like gazpacho (unless you like hot-spacho) and ceviche themselves soups? There’s certainly a case that they are. And if meat and heat aren’t requirements—not to mention the fact that cereal grains like rice are acceptable in soup—what’s to say that a bowl of Cheerios can’t count as a cold soup?


Well, that depends on whether or not we’re counting milk as a broth. Any broth-based meal served in a bowl would seem to fit the criteria for soup, regardless of its temperature. But while drinking a glass of milk is totally normal, you’d get some weird looks if you decided to chug a pint of chicken stock. Does the act of placing any liquid into a bowl automatically merit its reclassification as a broth?


Don’t even get me started about oatmeal’s role in all of this. Cereal’s devious sibling reintroduces the warmth that strict-constructionist soup-ists find essential, but it loses some of the innate cereal-ness. That’s because making oatmeal is more than a two-step process. Regardless, to introduce it into the discussion requires us to flip the script and define what cereal is. Not today, Satan.


So who really knows if cereal is a soup. Exploring the issue has me feeling like I’m further away from understanding the subject than when I started. It’s one of those debates that will rage indefinitely without arriving at any sort of meaningful consensus. I’m on the verge of dumping Lucky Charms into a bowl of Campbell’s chicken noodle in some sort of misguided attempt at compromise.

Perhaps what makes a bowl of breakfast cereal such a breakfast staple is that, much like the hot dog, it doesn’t fit neatly into the rigid categories we rely on to introduce reason and order into our chaotic world. All I do know is that referring to your next bowl of cereal as “the famous sweet breakfast soup we all know and love” is sure to spark a spirited discussion—or some coffee thrown in your face.

Hey wait a second, we can’t perfectly express what we mean when we speak because our language is full of so many words that have completely lost their meanings. When we say sunset, we don’t mean a setting sun because we realized the sun doesn’t set. What we literally say is not what we mean. We mean what we say, we stand by our message and firmly believe in it, but we can’t say what we mean. Maybe the Mad Hatter was right, maybe there is a difference between meaning what you say and saying what you mean. In Chinese, tang (汤) is soup... Unless you're talking about sour plum juice, which is suanmei tang (杨梅汤, literally sour plum soup). Usually, juice is zhi (汁), which applies to both fruit juice and also the juices released from cooked meat or sweet potatoes... Unless you're talking about bile (胆汁, dan zhi, literally "gallbladder juice") or brains (脑汁, nao zhi, literally "brain juice") as in the Chinese equivalent to the phrase "racking my brains" (绞尽脑汁, jiao jin nao zhi, literally "exhaustedly wring out your brain juice").

AAAAH I love this subject. The Norwegian translation of "I cannot stand this" is "jeg kan ikke fordra dette". It's relatively easy to translate the sentence: I = jeg, cannot = kan ikke, stand = fordra, this = dette. But what in the world does "fordra" mean? Just like English speakers never (or at least, rarely) say "I can stand this", you'd never say "jeg fordrar dette" in Norwegian, "fordra" actually sounds very negative, and people tend to interpret the word itself as a synonym to hate, dislike, etc.. Just wanted to share because I love the topic, I find it incredibly fascinating that we wouldn't say (as Michael used as an example) anyone's rupting the class in contrast to someone disrupting the class. You would think that the words have a similar relation to that of respect and disrespect, but in daily conversation, they don't seem to.

Terms like sunrise are phenomenological because they describe our subjective experience of phenomena rather than from an absolute objective viewpoint.


Buildings are called that because -ing was originally a suffix for making abstract nouns out of verbs and never used for making present participles. The original suffix for present participle is -ind. The -in' of I'm buildin', they're doin', etc. is from this -ind suffix and not from -ing.

In italian, words like "salad" and "soup" are well separated and defined. As soup we always mean that there is something solid completely sunk in something liquid, or just something liquid. As salad, instead, we always mean that there are vegetables in it, raw ones such as carrots, tomatoes and so on. Cereal, for us, wouldn't be neither a soup or a salad. It is  just a dessert

The reason why you call it a "Drawing" instead of a "Drawn" is, that the suffix -ing is rather related to the old germanic word "taga-thing" which means "assembly" and got over the years a new meaning: "Thing" or "Stuff" (related to the latin word "res publica", public matter/thing). Even in german we've got this suffix. We say also "Zeichnung" which is a compound of "zeichnen" (to draw) and the nominal suffix "-ung". So, literally a "drawing" means actually a "draw(n) thing/stuff".

And cereal is about much of a soup as much as a sausage is the same as a Frankfurter or a bratwurst.
However it can't be considered a soup, but it can't be considered a salad, why?
A larger majority of soups are prepared and served hot, gispatcho maybe an exception, but I don't even call that a soup, it's just glorified spiced tomato juice that tastes like nothing.
So you could call it a salad... Oh wait... Most salads are made with DRY ingredients, infact all of them are, very rarely does a salad call for using something as liquid as milk, or even water. Water is how you prep your vegetables, not serve them.

It's a good question, so let me take a crack at it. If I were to take a plate of chicken and pasta, that's what you'd call it. But if I were then to put it in a broth, it'd be chicken noodle soup. If I were to take lettuce and dressing, you'd call it lettuce and dressing. But if I were to add tomatoes, you'd call it a salad. Using this we can determine that a soup is classified by whether a not a liquid is involved, whereas a salad is classified by it's solid components, not by a liquid. Now tell me, do you stop calling Lucky Charms Lucky Charms when you pour in milk? No, but if you were to take a bowl of oats and milk and add in marshmallows, you'd call it Lucky Charms. Therefore, cereal is a salad, not a soup.

I love this episode. I used to do this with my old best friend in nursery (when I was 5). We started talking about santa clause one day, then theorised on him being a woman, one topic leading to the next, two five year olds trying to unerstand the world. I miss him. We ended on dinosaurs and I was so excited to discuss them with him the next day in nursery but I broke my arm and didn't go to nursery again (because it was near the end of the year). I don't think I've ever had such an imagination-driven conversation since then. I wish I could meet him again, see who he grew up to become (I'm only 16, but still, most of your personality is formed by now) I have no idea what his surname was and can barely recall his first name-Konrad, but I can remember our vivid conversations like a narration of the world, unfolding with every excited word. I matured from discussing Santa clause and dinosaurs to time travel, multiverses and higher dimensions and I wonder if he's the same. Now, i have no one to share my thoughts and ideas with, because my friends are more keen to discuss what a boy tweeted at them than quantum mechanics :(. I hope to meet someone like that again, and this time not lose them :(

The reason why cereal is not soup is because soup broth is made by extracted taste from solid food items such as meat or vegetables. Other ingredients are added to the broth: mostly vegetables and solid meat. The only grain ever included in soup is rice or a noodle.

Cereal doesn’t truly include milk. Cereal is by itself and typically served with milk on it, however, milk is not required for cereal to be cereal. Broth is required for soup to be soup.

The fundamentals of a salad are any of the various “usually cold dishes” including raw greens, vegetables and toppings. It is served with dressing or small pieces of food, or usually mixed with a dressing or set in gelatin.

Cereal consists of grains and dried products, such as raisins or nuts.

However, because cereal is so loosely constructed, with completely solid grain products such as whole grain Cheerios, you can argue that you can add cereal to salad. However, adding cereal to salad doesn’t make cereal, itself, salad.

So in the end cereal, is just cereal.

Yes,the correct way to eat cereal

The milk is a condiment.
In soup, the base is an ingredient you need to make soup soup, and it's added during the manufacture / process of cooking.
Putting something on a food after the food is complete in its plain form is called using a condiment.
The fact that people do eat it dry, I think, further reinforces that the milk is a condiment.

We add lots of condiments and toppings to cereal. Milk is one of them.

These kinds of videos are obviously full of purposeful misdirections to prove a point. So there's no value in either taking them as fact, or wasting time pointing out why they're incorrect.

I will leave one major flaw that questions the integrity of the entire video. "Eke name" and "nekename" are middle english words formed before there was a standard dictionary, and during a time when the evolution of words happened through local speakers writing words phonetically.

There is nothing significant about its formation from most other words in modern english. It's a terribly misleading example that didn't bother to mention that the corruption happened in what is effectively another language.

the phrase "go to bed" is a grammatical error. A bed is a certain type of furniture, just like tables and chairs. so saying "go to bed" is like saying "go to table" or "go to chair". This is the same as saying "go to sleep". The opposite of sleep is wake up, so imagine saying "go to wake up". Also, the phrase "wake up" is... well, we can't really say it's a grammatical error, because the only time we use the word "wake" is when we use the word "up" after it. but it still doesn't make sense, if you think about it. when we "wake up" we don't go "up".

Isn't "reduplicate" a poor term? It has an air of irony to it because the prefix is redundant, as is the definition, but the words it's describing aren't REduplicated. They are simply duplicated. The first word (e.g. "soup") is stated once, then duplicated. It's not "soup soup soup"- the original word is only duplicated once, to make "soup soup."

The American English, used to be considered a dialect of the British English, which was a super conservative and protected language to the point where you can literally get a fine for using a foreign word such as the  French word "soupe" or "salade". This came to no surprise since the French started it by fining anybody who used the word "computer" instead of "ordinateur" or "walkman" instead of "baladeur". The American English on the other hand didn't have these limitations, it just grew including several words from the French, German, Spanish, etc. We find words such as: "a priori" ; "zeitgeist"; or "kindergarten" who made into main stream academia. ironically they are the same words that would've gotten you into trouble had you used on national TV or Radio in France or England. Which adds to the credit of the American English, which is constant evolution.

The Dutch word for "building" is "gebouw". "Bouwen" means "to build" and to create a present perfect we prefix it with "ge-" and add a "d" (or sometimes t) at the end for regular verbs. examples: "schilderen" (to paint) "geschilderd" (painted), "wandelen" (to walk) "gewandeld" (walked). "Bouwen" (to build) "gebouwd" (built)... So the Dutch word for "built" is "gebouwd", it seems the noun version "gebouw" dropped the "d" for some reason... However, I find it interesting that we actually use the word in the state of the building process already being finished whereas in English the word is used in the state of the building is still in process of being built... :P ( This actually blows my mind right now because I have never thought about the nouns being derived from verbs! )

Another example of how broad names of food types can be was the 1991 tribunal here in the UK (hi!) where it had to be decided, for tax purposes, whether Jaffa Cakes should be classified as a cake or a biscuit. In the UK, chocolate-covered biscuits incurs a VAT tax, whilst chocolate-covered cakes does not (that's common law for you).

This lead to lengthy discussions as what constituted a 'cake' and what constituted a 'biscuit'. A long list of criteria to assess a food to determine its cake or biscuit status had to be decided upon, such as its size, the presence of sponge, and how you eat it. In the end, the tribunal decide that Jaffa Cakes were, indeed, cakes. Thank goodness that's all cleared up!

Mm, nounified verbs. We see something similar done in German (English is still technically a Germanic language), where you have the verb bauen for build or construct, and the noun Gebäude for "building" in the noun sense. We can see that the modification to the verb in order to create the noun in German is more contrasted from the German verb forms; the nearest the verb gets to the noun is "gebaut" (built). "Drawing" is handled a little differently, however, and in fact in a way that much more closely parallels the English strategy. The words for the verb and noun in German are zeichnen and Zeichnung, respectively, with the -ung ending being pretty much a 1:1 equivalent to the English -ing ending. However, while English also uses the -ing ending to form a verb in the progressive aspect, German does not; it rather uses an ending of -end (e.g. zeichnend, bauend) for the equivalent of the English progressive aspect, while the -ung ending is strictly for substantives (nouns). Thus we see once again that German manages to avoid ambiguity in the verb and "nounified verb" forms.

In conclusion, German is a superior language to English. :)

interesting paradox that mathematically proves there is NO ONE IN THE ENTIRE UNIVERSE.

- the universe is infinite
- therefore there are an infinite number of planets
- however, we know there are some uninhabited planets in the universe (e.g. Jupiter)
- this means there is a finite number of inhabited planets
- any finite number divided by infinity is so small that it can be called 0
- therefore there are 0 inhabited planets
- RESULT: no one exists

If you never play the game, you will always win. But if you always win, then the world becomes a boring place. I think a lot of the general YouTube comments that exist in this video alone are of people who are tired of winning so easily, and want to instead win an argument, Or maybe the want to lose. Or at least they want to try and throw a wrench in to see what happens.

If you look deep enough into any subject, you'll find there are all sorts of fallacies that remain unexplained, rules that are made up as we go along, and understandings that the majority of people come to accept, even if they are wrong. The video about misnomers are a brilliant example of that, especially when all along the internet has been full of Euclid diagrams, we still call them Venn diagrams. Probably because it sounds and writes better than crediting the godfather of modern geometric theory.

It's amazing that humanity had lived so long and had done so well, using ideas that had been made up on the fly. Sound reasoning behind the ideas that persist yes, but still, a fair bit of what we believe, do and believe we do, for all practical context, came out the arse of everyone who made the ideas up.

If you found all of the above stupid, you are probably the vast majority of people who will gloss over this post, using leftover survival instincts from when humanity were more nomadic (and in turn, more active) to find the point of the video. But in discovering this, do you lose the game? Or do you win? Why even try to come up with win / loss conditionals for comprehension and understanding when everything around you with a modicum of abstract sophistry is contextual and made up?

Along the lines of cereal being a form of "soup" (and I do feel that "soup," in which the liquid medium causes the entire serving to behave like a liquid, compared to "salad," in which the liquid is merely a "drippy" coating on separate solid bites, is more accurate), I realized a few years back that French toast* could also be called a "bread omelet."

* For those not familiar with this American -- and possibly British, I'm not sure -- English term, it is the result of soaking bread in scrambled eggs to the point that it almost falls apart, but the egg-soaked bread is fried in a skillet or on a grill to make a soft toast-like slice of bread.  After all, it is the egg that holds it together more than the bread, so it can be thought of as an omelet with bread permeating the egg.

Thus, an illustration of the paradox of the human condition. In this case, we wish to know everything or at least have a language that perfectly conveys an idea and sentiment to whoever it's spoken to. But at the same time, to have this would result in losing something that we wouldn't want to give up and can scarcely imagine living without. Here's another: we want everyone to be able to live forever and be healthy, but at the same time, we want everyone to be able to have as many children as they want. And, we wouldn't want to live in a world where there are no children. I imagine that if we discovered a way to make everyone live forever, but had to give up children at the same time (to prevent the quick overpopulation of the Earth), people would rue the day. Most would eventually find it to be the worst choice ever made and we'd all wish for there to be a child in the world. We want what we can't have and what we would be sorry we got. And, we want that badly! We are inherently, therefore, irrational beings. As long as we are irrational beings, no amount of technology will really change what we are nor solve the things that deeply trouble us. Only technology that can make us into fundamentally rational beings will really change humanity. Maybe that's a new horror awaiting us.

6:30 This is a case of language being behind scientific understanding. The words "sunrise" or "sunset" is much older than the understanding that the Earth moves. Infact there are even errors in books and movies that forget that the Earth moves. Often a condition of time travel in science fiction is that the machine moves through time, not space. When Marty drove from 1986 to 1959 in Back to the Future he was still in the same place relive to Earth. But he would also have had to move through space because the Earth had moved (quite a long way) between 1959 and 1986.
And yet we drive ON the parkway and we park IN the driveway.

You have holidays like Martin Luther King day and Presidents' Day, which are holidays of course, but then you have holidays like Valentine's Day and Christmas which are REALLY holidays. They're holiday holidays.

But then we have an entire season called "The Holidays" during which several holidays occur in quick succession. Several of these, like Christmas and Thanksgiving, are also holiday holidays. These holiday holidays which occur during "The Holidays" are HOLIDAY holiday holidays.

But then we have holidays like Halloween and Valentine's Day that occur near this large cluster of holidays, and could be considered part of "The Holidays" and thus be HOLIDAY holiday holidays, but they aren't quite as close to the big cluster as Christmas and Thanksgiving, which implies that Christmas and Thanksgiving are HOLIDAY HOLIDAY holiday holidays.

Great video. The rpoblem with language is that it's not really organized properly - they just sort of happen, like that there is no opposite of 'disgruntled', or why there is a k in 'knife' that you don't pronounce.

And I can comfort people with that this is something that probably every single language suffers from, and this chaos makes it harder to learn languages. It gets even worse when you have a language that has evolved beside it's old self, turning into a mutant, like American English: is it 'lift' or 'elevator'? 'Armour' or Armor'? 'Torch' or 'Flashlight'? 'Waggon' or wagon'? The examples are endless, and for me as a non-English native speaker it also makes me sound like an American hit in the head with an Oxford dictionary or something since I might mix and match both languages or dialects.

But, this is also kind of the charm with languages, and I recommend everyone to at least learn one foreign language.

building and drawing come from a time in English when these were nouns that described the act or the result of the act of a verb. Over time, we started saying that we were "on —ing" indicating that we were in the middle of the act, and that stuck. Intransitive sentences used it too, so rather than saying that the house was being built, we'd say "the house was on building". The "on" reduced to "a (pronounced 'uh')" and eventually disappeared. So when someone says "I'm a rockin' and a rollin'" they're actually harkening back to an earlier, version of English, when the "a" was still there.


Nick name came from re-bracketing by an eke name -> a nekename. Also, eke meant "other" as well as "also". Literally "an other name" or in modern parlance, "another name".

I do not think that cereal is either soup or salad, as cereal is still cereal without milk, whereas soup is not soup without broth.  The word cereal actually means:
1.  any plant of the grass family yielding an edible grain, as wheat, rye, oats, rice, or corn.
2.  the grain itself.
3.  some edible preparation of it, especially a breakfast food.
Therefore, cereal is simply just cereal, it is not some unusual category of food but rather a specific type of food.

Everyone seems to be confused.  The video was not about cereal, soup, or salad.  The beginning question was a introduction to the topic.  The topic was the way words develop and change meaning.  It's a linguistics video, and for a word nerd like me, I found it fascinating.  I didn't know doubling a word for emphasis or clarity was called reduplication!  And I loved the quote by Emily Dickinson at the end.  :)

I don't know why everyone is confused that the topic wasn't actually cereal or soup.  Michael titles a lot of his videos in this way; he'll take the topic and turn the topic into an interesting and related question and make that the title of the video.  Nothing new or unusual here, folks.

I'm sure this comment will be lost among the hundreds of thousands of others, but I must at least express my sentiments. I feel that Vsauce is not as informational as it used to be. In its early videos, it stayed fairly on topic with all of its "deviations" pertaining to its original question. It seems of late (being, oh, the last 6 months to a year or so), that it has become a bait and switch. They entice you with a juicy click-bait (which in this case is rather dull and I only clicked on it because of Vsauce's reputation) title, and then go on to explore other topics that are barely, if even at all, related to the title.

Don't get me wrong, they teach me things I didn't know before, but instead of learning about, say what temperature really means, I learn tiny, bite sized, pieces of what soup means, what salad means, nuances of the English language, nuances of other languages, dog dicks, punctuation marks, etc.

Not that anyone cares, but that was my two cents. Anyone care to, or able to comment or like?

By my standards, a soup is defined by the obligatory presence of a liquid phase. (It still is a soup if it's simply broth)

Salad, on the other hand, is defined by its coldness and the obligatory presence of a solid phase. (It still is a salad without any dressing)

Cereals, a case apart, are defined by their coldness and the obligatory presence of both liquid and solid phases.

So, cereals aren't soup because they cannot still be called cereals without their solid phase and neither can they be called salad because they need their liquid phase.

I vote cereal is like fries with ketchup.  It's not a soup because oatmeal is a cereal and it's not soupy because we use the word soupy to describe poorly made oatmeal.  It's not a salad because it's cooked, and salad salads are not cooked.  I think it's more like fries and ketchup because you can eat cereal without milk and it's still considered cereal, it's still the same level of snack or meal.  The milk, like a condiment, is a preference.  BAM.

Anyone who finds this discourse on language interesting should check out the linguistic philosophical idea of "sorites paradox".  It gives a great idea on the subjective nature of how we use language.  Sorite was an ancient greek philosopher so obviously he used Greek language, but the idea is still applicable.  Let's say I take a pound of sand and pour on a table.  Most everyone who's english would agree that that bunch of sand is a "heap" or a "pile" of sand.  Sorite then asks us to theoretically start taking grains away, so let's say I take one grain off that huge bunch, is it still a pile or a heap?  Most would say yes, so let's take another grain away, is it still a heap?  What about another, and another, and another?  At what point does that "heap" of sand cease to be a "heap"?  Is there any objective means of judging such a concept?  Sorite actually took it to it's logical conclusion arguing that, since there's no concrete means of judging given the language when that "heap" ceases to be a "heap" simply from removing one single grain, then one grain of sand (and indeed even NO grains) must, logically, constitute a "heap".

It's really an interesting concept from an existential framework, it paints quite vividly how language is (as he says at the end of this video) something that kind of only works as a sort of adapting mechanism, a means of imperfectly conveying feelings and thoughts that, on an existential level, we will never be able to convey completely to another person.  We may be cut off and isolated in these "fleshy prisons" on an existential level, but through language we can to a degree plug in to each other and convey internal thoughts and ideas to SOME degree to another person.  The Paradox just points out just how imperfectly that conveyance actually is, since every single person is going to have a different point at thich the "heap" becomes "not a heap".  Just thought that was a fascinating idea kind of in line with the linguistic focus of this video...have my doubts michael will even read this though given how many thousands of posts an hour the guy gets, can't expect him to see them all :) would love to see a video on that idea though with his style of discourse, would be very cool.

So... what about surgery, music, and sex? We treat these as nouns... but they should be a verb. They are innately an action. I can't pick up a music. And it isn't a state of being like an emotion either. It is pitches, arranged over time. The time is essential. but you play music like you play tag (a game, that is a set of words much like an algorithm). Sex is most defiantly an action, but I can't go sex someone or go sexing, I'd have to have sex with them. Just as I need to have surgery, or perform it.

Are these still verbal nouns? Or are they their own thing? Because it isn't a noun we use a verb to describe. It's a noun, that should be a verb.

Simply English is a mixture of many different languages. That's why if you analyse, many worlds don't make any sence..

Now the word analyze above doesn't have any meaning in English,
comes from the Greek word: ανάλυση,

The best translation to English is resolution:
re (means again) solution (means solution) so we have,
ανά (translates to again) λυση (translates to solution).

Another example in Greek,
sunrise is called: ανατολή , sounds like /a.na.tɔ.ˈli/,
which comes from the word: ανατολή,
meaning: east. So the sun rises from the east.

sunset is called: δύση , sounds like deeshe,
which comes from the word: δύση,
meaning: west. So the sun sets at west.

This is why I hate when people suddenly get so concerned with the origin of words when they disagree on what the definition of the word should be. For example, homophobia, which is a fear or dislike of homosexuals and/or homosexuality. People use the fact that it contains the suffix 'phobia' to argue that they're not homophobic because they only hate gay people, they're not afraid of them. Yet they don't argue to change words like lunacy (luna meaning moon), or the months September, October, November, December (because they're the ninth to twelfth months, not the seventh to tenth as the names would suggest.) The current definition always wins out above the meaning of the individual parts of the word. Similarly, someone can identify as bisexual and be attracted to men, women, and non-binary people. People always say these people can't be bisexual, but there's really no other term (nonbinary genders can't really be counted, and if you aren't attracted to every single gender, pansexual's not accurate either.) The funny thing is, these same people have no problem calling it a bicycle, even when there's training wheels on it. If they really cared about prefixes, they'd be calling it a quadrocycle.

cute introduction to etymology and some linguistics. would it blow your mind if i threw epistemology in? not only are categories fuzzy... the MEANING of words is itself fuzzy. we can only "explain"/"clarify" a word (or worse, an intention) using other words. it is essentially a self-referential system of not just idioms, but "meanings".

words are associated with the ideas they refer to, but often arbitrarily (etymology), and often without true precision. an "understanding" of any particular idea is pretty much just a lot of assumptions. we assume that the words attempting to refer to some particular idea would be interpreted in the same way by both the speaker and the listener.

in other words (heh), a speaker A chooses a set of words B to represent some idea C to a person D. from A to D, there are at least 3 steps where meaning can be assumed to be standardised, but fail to actually be so. language (from B to C), is often assumed to be a stable system; but how person A perceives B to C can differ markedly from how person D perceives it.

apart from social misunderstandings, this interpretation-fuzziness could even extend to neurological perceptions: is the red that i see, the same red that you see? is the pain i feel the same sensation you would call pain? are we enjoyomg the same melodic timbre when we listen to a piece of music we both like? when i feel lazy, is it the same set of feelings as when you feel lazy?

the final frontier is this: just how imprecise are words at conveying ideas between two separate consciousnesses? is there any way to reduce the disparity to zero?

In my opinion, cereal can be either a soup or a salad, depending on the ratio of dry cereal to milk. If the mass of the milk and the mass of the cereal is at a 50:50 ratio or higher, I would consider it soup. That said, if the ratio of milk to cereal is lower than 50:50 then I would consider it salad. Cereal can be either soup or salad, but never soup AND salad. In any case, however, cereal could also be considered simply:- Cereal, with milk as a topping.

Wouldn't reduplication be if you said "salad salad salad salad"? Isn't "salad salad" just duplication? As to whether cereal is soup, technically it probably is, if you use the word soup in its more general sense (as opposed to the more specific sense in which we typically use it). I think calling cereal a salad is a stretch. On the other hand, maybe defining cereal in terms of something else is nonsense. Maybe cereal is a unique classification in itself. If we're going to start shoehorning things into categories which they don't really belong, then we could do the same thing to all things: soup that's dry enough could be called a salad, and salad with enough dressing could be called a soup. Thus, categorization - a way of organizing our world - is rendered meaningless and thus ineffective. That's why equivocation is bad...

The abbreviation RPG means Role-playing game. Originally used to describe the games popularized by D&D, the abbreviation worked well. Later RPG evolved and moved into other mediums and so the Live-RPG and the CRPG was born (computer role-playing game). After this Live-RPG got its own abbreviation: LARP (Live Action Roleplay, there is an implied game at the end but it is not in the abbreviation). CRPG however performed a coup. In essence the CRPG became more prevalent and accepted than RPG and it toke over the term RPG. Today this means that if you say you are going to play RPG people assume you are playing a computer game. Presently the old RPG is missing an abbreviation. Some simply use RP but this is often also misunderstood and you are often forced to go to the cumbersome tabletop-RPG.

A book is a book (made of paper); and e-book is an electronic book. I'd never call an e-book a book.
Mail is mail; the kind that comes in your mailbox in an envelope or postcard. Email is electronic mail. I would never call email mail.
A cell phone is a type of phone. All of the classic versions of phones, and cell phones are phones. Saying "cell phone" is just describing which type of phone you're talking about.
A smart phone is separate; it is a gadget that has a phone, and other non-phone features.

I feel like dry cereal is the meal and the milk is the condiment. Dry cereal can be eaten plain and you'd still be eating cereal, where as you cannot eat lettuce plain and be eating a salad and you can't eat, say, chicken plain and be eating a soup. Milk is not a necessary component like how icing is not necessary on a cake for it to be a cake and ketchup on french fries is not a necessary component for them to be french fries. You could then argue that dressing, the liquid component, isn't necessary in a salad but I'd argue that salads are whatever people commonly agree on calling a salad considering potato salad and fruit salad share almost no resemblance to traditional salads but we still call them salads. So there are pretty much no requirements to be a salad (you can very well have a salad on either a plate or a bowl) except people have to commonly agree on calling it a salad. So until I'm eating sugary salads for breakfast it's a meal and condiment. I just wrote an essay on how to classify cereal, someone please give me my caring-way-too-much-about-stupid-bullshit award.

Speaking of fuzzy categories, what about the turning point between hot and cold? Think about a shower faucet:- there's usually an indicator of where to turn the knob to get hot or cold water. We know that if you turn the knob all the way one direction or another, it is definitely hot or definitely cold. But someone had to decide when making that indicator at exactly what point in the middle of the two extremes that the water stopped being hot, and started being cold, and there is no real exact point where you could say with 100% accuracy that the water is no longer hot or cold.

The question about cereal reminds me of a question that my step-father used to ask me.  Is a piano a stringed or percussion instrument.  A piano has strings like a s stringed instrument, but the strings are hit by tiny little hammers, like a percussion instrument.

Well, the answer is that it's neither, it's a chordophone, a class of instruments all of it's own.  I think cereal is like that.  It's not a soup, it's not a salad, it's just cereal.  It may have characteristics like the two other categories, but it's something completely different.

"In the beginning were the Words, and the Words made the world. I am the Words. The Words are everything. Where the Words end, the world ends. You cannot go forward in an absence of space."

Our entire world is ruled by words, symbols and logos. Almost everything we can imagine, we have given its own designation. It's our language which allows us to communicate with eachother and share our own understandings of how things are. Our profound ability to recognize patterns is what, at our core, makes us human. Be it science, art, philosophy or anything else. Everything you can think of, it all is meaningless without you to give it meaning. The problem with how we communicate, however, is that language is subjective. Something for one person could mean something totally different for another. So in the end what value does our language hold? If the sole purpose to communication is to allow us to understand eachother and our language is incapable of properly doing so, then is it not a failed system? The truth is that we cannot fully understand another person's experiences without being that person. Isn't that ironic?

In informal communications, definitions are just guidelines. Most of the words we know and use are not from looking things up in a dictionary. They are mostly from the contexts of previous conversations and other experiences in our lives.

It's annoying when people get pedantic about definitions. The goal is communication, so choosing a word that is an approximation of what is meant is fine by me. It provides a baseline that may, if necessary, be clarified by further discussion.

English is a bizarre language, but then again, most languages are bizarre. Languages spawn from cultures, where basic sounds that we once made when humankind began as a species as an emotional reaction to something, eventually gained syntax and direct meaning. English spawns from multiple sources, from the Anglo-Saxxon to Germanic origin, Latin, and Greek. It shares with it, common ancestry from Scandinavian languages as well. Why is "I" from English, "Jeg," in Danish, "Jag" in Swedish with similar pronunciation, but "Ich" in German? The Old English form of I is "Ic," which sounded like "itch." In the world, there are over 6,000 known languages, both real and made up, and languages that have disappeared into the ancient past, such as the Bo language that was mentioned on a previous Vsauce. It is a reminder that we are all linked together in some way, not just genetically speaking as a species, but mentally, through the languages we create over our lifetimes, and the commonalities they share with other languages. The way I see it, language is only needed to commuicate. So it doesn't matter how many flaws there are in the language you use, as long as what you mean to communicate is understood by the person you are communicating to.

For example, this shape: <3 has turned into a symbol called the 'heart' and is also a symbol of love. This isn't what the organ that pumps our blood looks like, nor does the heart actually contain emotions, but if you say "I <3 you", meaning "I love you", and the person you tell that to understands that you mean to say "I love you", then it's okay if the sentence we say doesn't really make sense...because it still does.

You can, in fact, be gruntled :)

However, it's not clear whether it's a positive (http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/gruntled?s=t) or a negative (http://dailyuw.com/archive/2013/01/14/opinion/wills-word-week-disgruntled#.VKX1hSuG98E).

To use the word 'Gruntled' today, would likely be as a positive, the opposite of 'Disgruntled', but that, as the first link states, is a back-formation. 'Gruntled', in the positive sense, originated from 'Disgruntled', which makes little sense to me, as most words using the 'Dis-' affix use it to make negative another word. In my thinking, the word made negative (in this case 'gruntled') would have had to be in place before the affix could be placed before it!

But in the sense that 'to gruntle' in its original meaning is a negative thing, meaning 'to displease' or 'to annoy', shouldn't 'dis-gruntle' mean...'to please' or 'to dis-annoy', making it the positive version of the original word...

ekename is still called økenavn in Norwegian (although considered a bit archaic now; kallenavn would be more commonly used in its place, which just literally means call name, as in the name you actually call someone by). I had no idea that nickname and økenavn evolved from the same root until I learned about this rebracketing thing. An example of a rebracketing that has gone the other way btw, would be apron. It used to be "a napron" and has turned into "an apron" as opposed to "an eke name" where the indefinite article lost the n to the word itself and became "a nickname"
